facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 446 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 446 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 9, 1958 of Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 85 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 9, 1958 of the Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 85 of 1956.

facts.text: Village of Mothirambedu is one of the shrotriem villages in Chingleput district in State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Mothirambedu village is one of the shrotriem villages in the Chingleput district in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Respondent purchased Mothirambedu village from P. Anathapadmanabacharlu under sale deed dated July 10, 1946 for Rs. 26,000 and was in possession.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent purchased the same from one P. Anathapadmanabacharlu under a sale deed dated July 10, 1946, for a sum of Rs. 26,000/-, and was in possession and enjoyment thereof.

facts.text: Government of Madras issued notification under s.3 of the Act on December 12, 1950 taking over Mothirambedu as zamindari estate.

anchor.surface_text: On December 12, 1950, the Government of Madras issued a notification under s. 3 of the Act taking over the said village as a zamindari estate.

facts.text: Government took possession of Mothirambedu village on January 3, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Government took possession of the same on January 3, 1951.

facts.text: Respondent filed O.S. No. 22 of 1954 on March 15, 1954 in Subordinate Judge Chingleput against State for declaration that notification was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: On March 15, 1954, the respondent filed O.S. No. 22 of 1954 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Chingleput, against the State of Madras for a declaration that the said notification of his village as zamindari estate under the said Act was illegal and void.

facts.text: In plaint, respondent claimed village was ryotwari estate within Madras Estates Land Act and did not vest in State, but plea given up.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint he claimed that the said village was ryotwari estate within the meaning of the Madras Estates Land Act and, therefore, it did not vest in the State. But that plea was subsequently given up and nothing need be said in that regard.

facts.text: State filed written statement asserting village formed part of Tirumazhy Zamindari, separately registered in Collector's office, hence zamindari estate.

anchor.surface_text: The State filed a written-statement asserting that the said village formed part of Tirumazhy Zamindari, that it was separately registered in the office of the Collector and that, therefore, it was a zamin estate within the meaning of the said Act.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge Chingleput held suit village was zamin estate, notification legal and binding.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge, Chingleput, held that the suit village was a zamin estate and that, therefore, the said notification was legal and binding on the respondent.

facts.text: Madras High Court held not proved zamin village but whole inam village, granted declaration notification illegal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court of Judicature at Madras held that it was not proved that the said village was a zamin village, but it was a whole inam village. On that finding, it granted the plaintiff a declaration...

facts.text: State contended village included in assets of zamindari at permanent settlement, continued as part till abolished.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State contended that the said village was included in the assets of the zamindari at the time of the permanent settlement, that it continued to be a part of the said estate till it was abolished under the Act.

facts.text: Respondent argued village granted as shrotriem before permanent settlement to Nattuvar, pre-existing tenure not disturbed, held as under-tenure from zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. T. V. R. Tatachary, learned counsel for the respondent, on the other hand, argued that the said village was granted as a shrotriem before the permanent settlement to a person holding the office of a Nattuvar...

facts.text: Cowle granted by Lionel Place to Rangasami Mudali dated December 10, 1796 conferring mirasi of Mothirambedu village.

anchor.surface_text: The earliest document on record is Ex. A-7, the certified copy of cowle granted by Mr. Lionel Place, Collector of Honorable Company's Jageer to Rangasami Mudali dated December 10, 1796.

facts.text: Genuineness of Ex. A-7 not in question.

anchor.surface_text: The genuineness of this document is not in question. It was filed by consent.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Mothirambedu held under permanent under-tenure, falls under s.3(2)(e) Madras Estates Land Act, under-tenure estate, not zamindari estate, notification void.

anchor.surface_text: As the village is held under a permanent under-tenure, it falls squarely under the definition of s. 3 (2) (e) of the Madras Estates Land Act and is, therefore, an estate thereunder and hence it is an under-tenure estate. As the under-tenure estate is excluded from the definition of zamin estate, the notification issued by the Government... is void...

facts.text: In 1921 suit between zamindar and tenants, character of village disputed, High Court in 1927 held not part of zamindari.

anchor.surface_text: What is more, the character of this village was in dispute in a suit between the zamindar and the tenants in the year 1921. That suit ultimately went up to the High Court and a Division Bench of the Madras High Court disposed of the appeal on November 23, 1927.

facts.text: Office of Nattuvar abolished at permanent settlement but Nattuvars allowed to retain shrotriem villages.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that at the time of permanent settlement in the Chingleput District, which was then described as a Jagir, the office of Nattuvar was abolished but the Nattuvars were allowed to retain the shrotriem villages granted to them.

facts.text: Shrotriem lands included in zamindari at permanent settlement, reversionary interest transferred to zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: This policy was implemented by including the shrotriems in the zamindari by transferring the Company's ultimate reversionary rights to the zamindar.

facts.text: Village held under permanent under-tenure from zamindar after permanent settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The tenure under the Government became an under-tenure under the zamindar, as the zamindar intervened between the Government and the Nattuvar.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate raises the question whether the village of Mothirambedu is a zamindari estate under the Madras Estates Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari Act, 1948 Madras Act XXVI of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act.

arguments.claim: Pre-settlement mokhasa/shrotriem villages included in zamindari assets held as permanent under-tenure per precedents Gopisetti and Narayanaswami

anchor.surface_text: Where a pre-settlement Mokhasa village was included in the assets of the zamindari it was held that the village was held under a permanent under-tenure... see Gopisetti Veeraswami v. Sagiraju...

holdings.text: The village of Mothirambedu is held under a permanent under-tenure and falls squarely under the definition of s. 3(2)(e) of the Madras Estates Land Act and is therefore an under-tenure estate.

anchor.surface_text: As the village is held under a permanent under-tenure, it falls squarely under the definition of s. 3 2  e  of the Madras Estates Land Act and is, therefore, an estate thereunder and hence it is an under-tenure estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical cowle Ex.A-7 granted permanent mirasi pre-PS to Nattuvar; PS policy abolished office but retained shrotriem lands by transferring reversionary interest to zamindar; analogous precedents (Gopisetti, Narayanaswami); 1927 HC finding not part of zamindari; rejected State evidence (Ex.B-2 unsigned undated, manuals ambiguous).

holdings.text: An under-tenure estate is excluded from the definition of zamindari estate under Section 2(16) of the Madras Estates Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the under-tenure estate is excluded from the definition of zamin estate,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of s.2(16) MEA excluding portions under s.3(2)(e) MELA from zamindari estate definition; village fits s.3(2)(e) as permanent under-tenure post-PS.

holdings.text: The notification issued by the Government under s.3 of the Act taking over the village as a zamindari estate is void.

anchor.surface_text: the notification issued by the Government on the basis that t is a zamin estate is void and the High Court rightly declared it as void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Village not zamindari estate but under-tenure estate excluded from Abolition Act vesting; s.3 notification only valid for zamindari estates.

holdings.text: To constitute a permanent under-tenure, it is not material whether the grant was pre-settlement or post-settlement, but where reversionary interest rests in the zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that to constitute an under-tenure it is number material whether the grant was a pre-,settlement or a post-settlement one, but what is important is, in whom the reversionary interest rests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustrations of pre/post PS grants; PS inclusion transfers reversion from govt to zamindar creating under-tenure; applied to shrotriem.

holdings.text: No presumption can be drawn from unsigned, undated statements without context or authentication.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot draw any presumption on an unsigned statement which does number even bear a date. This must, therefore, be ignored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex.B-2 lacks date, signature, provenance; internal evidence post-1800 but no proof acted upon at PS.

holdings.text: There is no justification to differ from the 1927 Madras High Court finding that the village is not part of the zamindari.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see any justification to take a different view from that accepted by the High Court in the year 1927.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No new material evidence; prior suit between zamindar and tenants; zamindar failed to produce sannad or records.
